commit_message:
validating/indexing extra attributes

Add the specification for handling validation and indexing/searching
based upon the extra attributes for the many different resources that
keystone manages/consumes.

Change-Id: Ic0b8327e144b169e441edf3b3a18b72a019fd03e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/32/190532/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================== Validated and Indexed Extra Fields ================================== `bp validated-and-indexed-extra-field <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ keystone/+spec/validated-and-indexed-extra-fields>`_ Keystone has supported the concept of Serialized LOB (Large Object) for any value that is not part of the defined attributes for a given resource (e.g. User, Group, Project, Domain, etc). Keystone does not currently validate nor provide a means to search based upon these arbitrary values. Problem Description =================== Deployers and Operators utilize the "extra" fields for a number of use cases such as billing information, data about what business unit a resource belongs to and much more. There have been many cases that these operators and deployers want to be able to validate these fields and/or searching based upon indexing these fields. Proposed Change =============== This spec is proposing two key changes: 1. Provide a way to validate these 'extra' fields via JSON Schema and ensure that only the defined fields are allowed in addition to the normal/baseline attributes. This would prevent typos or minor errors from storing data erroneously in the wrong value. The change would implement a CRUD interface to define for a given resource-type (e.g. User) where the deployer/operator could specify a JSON Schema definition for the additional attribute(s). These attributes would then be added to the normal JSON Schema validation at the RESTful API layer. Each of these attributes would initially only be marked as 'optional'. This will have no impact on the first-class attributes defined across all Keystone deployments (such as `username` for users). 2. At the definition time of the extra attribute, the deployer/operator could specify the attribute as indexed. This would signal to Keystone that it would need to internally manage the index (in a separate table or similar) of the attribute for the resource type. A new query param will be added (based upon this definition) for the defined resource-type (e.g. `/users?&extra_attr={attr_name}&value={attr_value}`). This will allow the user(s) of Keystone to search for a resource that has the defined attribute and (optionally) attribute value. Alternatives ------------ An alternative to having a CRUD interface for defining the attributes is to make the important attributes a core part of the resource objects themselves. The issue with making these extra attributes a first-class part of the resource is that it requires either direct customization by the deployer (changing Keystone's code) or having a number of these first-class attributes that many deployments do not need. Another alternative is to continue with the non-validated/unindexed extra attributes. The final alternative would be to deprecate and/or remove the extra attribute concept. This is unlikely to work due to moderate-to-widespread use. Security Impact --------------- For the most part there will be no significant security impact, as we are only adding new validated attributes for the resources. There is a slight improvement since Keystone will no longer allow any attribute to be passed to the API and stored without the deployer definition of the validator. The use of non-defined (with the new CRUD interface) extra attributes will be long term deprecated but initially requiring validation of all extra attributes will be optional. This will also allow the deployer/operator to prevent users from storing any arbitrary values into the Serialized LOB, causing a significant increase in storage use (and/or overhead for deserializing). Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- End users will be able to search on extra attributes and receive clear feedback that the extra attributes are either valid or invalid based upon the definition from the deployer/operator. Performance Impact ------------------ There should be no real performance impact. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployers will need to define the new validators for the extra attributes to make use of this feature and/or specify the attribute as indexed. Developer Impact ---------------- There should be a defined prefix for all "extra" attributes so that they are guaranteed to have no namespace conflicts with the first-class resource attributes. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- TBD Work Items ---------- * Develop CRUD interface for JSON Schema Validator of extra attributes * Connect the CRUD defined JSON Schema Validators to the Controller(s) so that validation can occur on the new attributes. * Define/implement the mechanism for indexing the extra attributes * Define/implement the API/Query parameters for querying based upon the extra attributes. * Specify the prefix / namespace in the resource objects for extra attributes so that they do not conflict with current/future first-class attributes. Dependencies ============ TBD Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation of the new API(s) and query parameters will nbeed to be created. References ========== N/A

commit_message:
No longer support configuring keystone under eventlet

This change removes devstack support for deploying keystone under
eventlet. This change should be merged as soon as development for
Mitaka has started (the stable/liberty branch has been cut) on
devstack.

Change-Id: I023ccc649c7ce674931ad638c6dd0d4c38a31e19
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/12/229112/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Eliminate the %(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d from the log format strings iniset $KEYSTONE_CONF DEFAULT logging_context_format_string "%(process)d %(levelname)s %(name)s [%(request_id)s %(user_identity)s] %(instance)s%(message)s" iniset $KEYSTONE_CONF DEFAULT logging_default_format_string "%(process)d %(levelname)s %(name)s [-] %(instance)s%(message)s" iniset $KEYSTONE_CONF DEFAULT logging_debug_format_suffix "%(funcName)s %(pathname)s:%(lineno)d" iniset $KEYSTONE_CONF DEFAULT logging_exception_prefix "%(process)d TRACE %(name)s %(instance)s" _config_keystone_apache_wsgi enable_apache_site keystone restart_apache_server tail_log key /var/log/$APACHE_NAME/keystone.log tail_log key-access /var/log/$APACHE_NAME/keystone_access.log
deleted_lines: if [ "$KEYSTONE_USE_MOD_WSGI" == "True" ]; then # Eliminate the %(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d from the log format strings iniset $KEYSTONE_CONF DEFAULT logging_context_format_string "%(process)d %(levelname)s %(name)s [%(request_id)s %(user_identity)s] %(instance)s%(message)s" iniset $KEYSTONE_CONF DEFAULT logging_default_format_string "%(process)d %(levelname)s %(name)s [-] %(instance)s%(message)s" iniset $KEYSTONE_CONF DEFAULT logging_debug_format_suffix "%(funcName)s %(pathname)s:%(lineno)d" iniset $KEYSTONE_CONF DEFAULT logging_exception_prefix "%(process)d TRACE %(name)s %(instance)s" _config_keystone_apache_wsgi fi if [ "$KEYSTONE_USE_MOD_WSGI" == "True" ]; then enable_apache_site keystone restart_apache_server tail_log key /var/log/$APACHE_NAME/keystone.log tail_log key-access /var/log/$APACHE_NAME/keystone_access.log else # Start Keystone in a screen window run_process key "$KEYSTONE_BIN_DIR/keystone-all --config-file $KEYSTONE_CONF" fi

commit_message:
Make acl_scenarios tests' keystonemiddleware cache work flexibly

Token cache keys in keystonemiddleware 2.0 are sha256 hashes of the
token key. This is _not_ the case in keystonemiddleware <2.0. This
change adjusts the FakeMemcache to support both types of key.

Change-Id: Idcba48b227e8921a67f5af27f723810704ae790b

commit_message:
Set attribute 'is_locked' of cluster as public

Removed the duplicated logic to calculate the cluster
is locked or not from UI.

Change-Id: I642015bf687b7135a2bea4a0494b453565b3d43f
Partial-Bug: #1519050

commit_message:
Dynamically find the extra partitioned block device

This provides support for using loopback devices for the extra
disk.

Change-Id: Ia61b32e27ba619d15860daa6a9ed75291dad1d06
Closes-bug: #1518641
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/05/248405/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Figure out the path to the partitioned device PARTDEV=$(fdisk -l /dev/${DEV} |tail -1 |awk '{print $1}') sudo pvcreate ${PARTDEV} sudo vgcreate kolla01 ${PARTDEV}

commit_message:
Convert gate to Ansible setup

To support multinode we must now distribute our setup to multiple
hosts. Instead of making special rules for this, we are going to
convert our existing setup to Ansible. This way both setup proceedures
take place in the exact same fashion.

Partially-Implements: blueprint multinode-gate
Change-Id: I43ece298bba994e9b5083403ef3cf6d4245cda6d

commit_message:
Xenapi: Handle missing aggregate metadata on startup

If the host added using aggregate function to slave host in
Xenserver environments, nova-compute does not start
because cannot get aggregate metadata information.

Co-authored-by: John Haan <yongiman@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Yoon Doyoul <ydoyeul@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Michael Still <mikal@stillhq.com>

Change-Id: Idc979d7b3a974f7f9f61e6cd3485bd7a7e0879ea
Closes-Bug: 1413475

commit_message:
Move the old release notes to a separate file

Preparation for reno adoption in a following patch

Change-Id: Ice4f45147ae9699a5be2c60c0ed247b893881d62
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/32/248932/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Release Notes ============= 2.2.2 ----- * improved support for listing a large number of filtered subnets * add --endpoint-type and OS_ENDPOINT_TYPE to shell client * made the publicURL the default endpoint instead of adminURL * add ability to update security group name (requires 2013.2-Havana or later) * add flake8 and pbr support for testing and building 2.2.0 ----- * add security group commands * add Lbaas commands * allow options put after positional arguments * add NVP queue and net gateway commands * add commands for agent management extensions * add commands for DHCP and L3 agents scheduling * support XML request format * support pagination options 2.0 ----- * support Neutron API 2.0

commit_message:
dyn-gen-physnet-set functions

Implement generate_bridge_mappings
Implement generate_physnet_vlan_ranges

CI disable, because next patch in the chain has valuable CI check.
Only functions located here. no calls.

Fuel-CI: disable
Change-Id: I0cfd3d38ab62d07216e767e391109fcac74691b4
blueprint: dyn-gen-physnet-set

added_lines: require 'puppet' require 'spec_helper' describe 'function for formating allocation pools for neutron subnet resource' do def setup_scope @compiler = Puppet::Parser::Compiler.new(Puppet::Node.new("floppy", :environment => 'production')) if Puppet.version =~ /^3\./ @scope = Puppet::Parser::Scope.new(@compiler) else @scope = Puppet::Parser::Scope.new(:compiler => @compiler) end @topscope = @topscope @scope.parent = @topscope Puppet::Parser::Functions.function(:generate_bridge_mappings) end describe 'basic tests' do before :each do setup_scope puppet_debug_override end let :network_scheme do {"transformations"=> [{"action"=>"add-br", "name"=>"br-fw-admin"}, {"action"=>"add-br", "name"=>"br-mgmt"}, {"action"=>"add-br", "name"=>"br-storage"}, {"action"=>"add-br", "name"=>"br-ex"}, {"action"=>"add-br", "name"=>"br-floating", "provider"=>"ovs"}, {"action"=>"add-patch", "bridges"=>["br-floating", "br-ex"], "provider"=>"ovs", "mtu"=>65000}, {"action"=>"add-br", "name"=>"br-prv", "provider"=>"ovs"}, {"action"=>"add-br", "name"=>"br-aux"}, {"action"=>"add-patch", "bridges"=>["br-prv", "br-aux"], "bridge"=>"br-mgmt", "name"=>"bond0.101"}, {"action"=>"add-port", "bridge"=>"br-storage", "name"=>"bond0.102"}], "roles"=> {"keystone/api"=>"br-mgmt", "neutron/api"=>"br-mgmt", "mgmt/database"=>"br-mgmt", "sahara/api"=>"br-mgmt", "heat/api"=>"br-mgmt", "ceilometer/api"=>"br-mgmt", "ex"=>"br-ex", "ceph/public"=>"br-mgmt", "mgmt/messaging"=>"br-mgmt", "management"=>"br-mgmt", "murano/api"=>"br-mgmt", "nova/api"=>"br-mgmt", "horizon"=>"br-mgmt", "nova/migration"=>"br-mgmt", "mgmt/memcache"=>"br-mgmt", "cinder/iscsi"=>"br-storage", "ceph/replication"=>"br-storage"}, "interfaces"=> {"eth5"=> {"vendor_specific"=>{"driver"=>"e1000", "bus_info"=>"0000:00:08.0"}}, "eth4"=> {"vendor_specific"=>{"driver"=>"e1000", "bus_info"=>"0000:00:07.0"}}, "eth3"=> {"vendor_specific"=>{"driver"=>"e1000", "bus_info"=>"0000:00:06.0"}}, "eth2"=> {"vendor_specific"=>{"driver"=>"e1000", "bus_info"=>"0000:00:05.0"}}, "eth1"=> {"vendor_specific"=>{"driver"=>"e1000", "bus_info"=>"0000:00:04.0"}}, "eth0"=> {"vendor_specific"=>{"driver"=>"e1000", "bus_info"=>"0000:00:03.0"}}}, "version"=>"1.1", "provider"=>"lnx", "endpoints"=> {"br-fw-admin"=>{"IP"=>["10.109.0.4/24"]}, "br-prv"=>{"IP"=>"none"}, "br-floating"=>{"IP"=>"none"}, "br-storage"=>{"IP"=>["192.168.1.1/24"]}, "br-mgmt"=>{"IP"=>["192.168.0.4/24"]}, "br-ex"=>{"IP"=>["10.109.1.4/24"], "gateway"=>"10.109.1.1"}} } end let :neutron_config do {"default_floating_net"=>"admin_floating_net", "database"=>{"passwd"=>"2eaczPxjQNxkR6qik3sZlsaW"}, "default_private_net"=>"admin_internal_net", "keystone"=>{"admin_password"=>"EanTYjYlXqzATHAriBPkllal"}, "L3"=>{"use_namespaces"=>true}, "L2"=>{"phys_nets"=>{"physnet2"=>{"bridge"=>"br-prv", "vlan_range"=>"1000:1030"}}, "base_mac"=>"fa:16:3e:00:00:00", "segmentation_type"=>"vlan"}, "predefined_networks"=>{ "admin_floating_net"=>{ "shared"=>false, "L2"=>{"network_type"=>"local", "router_ext"=>true, "physnet"=>'physnet2', "segment_id"=>nil}, "L3"=>{"nameservers"=>[], "subnet"=>"10.109.1.0/24", "floating"=>["10.109.1.130:10.109.1.254"], "gateway"=>"10.109.1.1", "enable_dhcp"=>false}, "tenant"=>"admin"}, "admin_internal_net"=>{ "shared"=>false, "L2"=>{"network_type"=>"vlan", "router_ext"=>false, "physnet"=>"physnet2", "segment_id"=>nil}, "L3"=>{"nameservers"=>["8.8.4.4", "8.8.8.8"], "subnet"=>"192.168.111.0/24", "floating"=>nil, "gateway"=>"192.168.111.1", "enable_dhcp"=>true}, "tenant"=>"admin"}}, "metadata"=>{"metadata_proxy_shared_secret"=>"uLLpFlxwX848GYnTUse2PjMp"} } end it "should exist" do Puppet::Parser::Functions.function(:generate_bridge_mappings).should == "function_generate_bridge_mappings" end it 'error if no arguments' do lambda { @scope.function_generate_bridge_mappings([]) }.should raise_error(ArgumentError, 'generate_bridge_mappings(): wrong number of arguments (0; must be 3)') end it 'should require one argument' do lambda { @scope.function_generate_bridge_mappings(['foo', 'wee', 'ee', 'rr']) }.should raise_error(ArgumentError, 'generate_bridge_mappings(): wrong number of arguments (4; must be 3)') end it 'should be able to return floating nets to bridge map' do expect(@scope.function_generate_bridge_mappings([neutron_config, network_scheme, { :do_floating => true, :do_tenant => true, :do_provider => false }])).to eq({'admin_floating_net'=>'br-prv'} ) end end end

commit_message:
Migrate libvirt volumes

This spec proposes using built-in libvirt volume transfer
methods to transfer libvirt volumes between compute nodes,
in order to facilitate cold migrations and resizes.

Spec for blueprint migrate-libvirt-volumes

Depends-On: Idc8e919627e2e01c2fa4599f15c9e2de614f41c3

Change-Id: I7b55d36e390207e7fea7e5ec75ccd29573850579
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/53/232053/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================================== Use Libvirt Storage Pool Methods to Migrate Libvirt Volumes =========================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/migrate-libvirt-volumes Currently, the libvirt driver only uses SSH (rsync or scp) to do cold migrations and resizes on non-shared storage. This requires SSH permissions between compute nodes, which is problematic for a number of reasons. Instead we can use the methods built in to libvirt's storage pool API to do migrations. NOTE: this proposal requires `Use libvirt storage pools`_ Problem description =================== The primary issue is that, currently, the Nova libvirt driver requires SSH access between compute nodes to perform cold migrations and resizes on non-shared storage. This presents several issues: * From a security perspective, providing SSH access between compute nodes is sub-optimal. Giving compute nodes SSH access could allow a compromised node to compromise other nodes and potentially inflict harm on a cloud. * From a setup perspective, it adds several extra steps to a setup: System administrators, or their setup tools, must generate a keypair for each compute node, and upload the public key to each of the other compute nodes. Use Cases --------- Deployer: This allows the deployer to not have to set up SSH access between compute nodes while still supporting non-shared-storage resizes and cold migrations, as long as the deployer is using the new libvirt storage pools image backend. None Proposed change =============== The functionality in this blueprint would only be used when the deployer is using the new libvirt storage pool image backend, and has enabled the :code:`[libvirt]vol_upload_migration` option. At migration time, a new volume would be created in the destination node's storage pool, and the methods virStorageVolDowload and virStorageVolUpload would be used to stream the contents of the disk between compute nodes (http://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-storage.html#virStorageVolUpload). In order to ensure secure migrations, libvirt should be configured to use one of the various forms of authentication and encryption that it supports, such as Kerberos (via SASL -- http://libvirt.org/auth.html) or TLS client certificates (http://libvirt.org/remote.html#Remote_libvirtd_configuration). Alternatives ------------ * Requiring shared storage for cold migrations and resizes: there are many OpenStack users who would like to be able to perform cold migrations and resizes without having shared storage. * Just setting up SSH keys between compute nodes: see the problem description * Temporarily provisioning SSH keys for the duration of the migration: While this somewhat mitigates the security issue and remove the extra setup steps, it still provides a window where the compute nodes are vulnerable. It would be much harder to secure, and would require having Nova be able to securely generate SSH keys. * Using an rsync daemon: People seemed to be averse to requiring an rsync daemon. Additionally, rsync daemon connections are not encryptable out of the box, although they can be run over stunnel. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- While this change does require two compute nodes' libvirt daemons to connect to each other, such a process is already done by live migration. While the disks would no longer be encrypted by SSH while transfering, system administrators could simply secure the libvirt connections instead (http://libvirt.org/auth.html). Libvirt supports TLS for encryption with x509 client certificates for authentication, as well as SASL for GSSAPI/Kerberos encryption and authentication. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ There are a couple potential performance issues: * Rsync compresses the contents to be transfered, but AFAIK libvirt does not (although this is being worked on in conjunction with the libvirt developers). This could result in more data being transfered over the network. * The actually streaming process requires some use of intermediary code to call the write function on the contents of the read function. One way would be using python as an intermediary (e.g. :code:`data = stream1.recv(1024*64); stream2.send(data)`, although the actual code would properly support async IO, detection of partial sends, etc). While this would be less performant than having C code which would do the transfer, I suspect there are ways in which we could optimize the code, or other methods (such as utilizing the libvirt command line client). Other deployer impact --------------------- In order for the new method to work, deployers would have to enable the libvirt daemon on each compute node to listen for remote libvirt connections (if live migrations are enabled, this has already been done). Such connections must be secured as noted in `Security Impact`_. Additionally the configuration option :code: `[libvirt]vol_upload_migration` would need to be enabled. This is especially important until we can guarantee the performance is on par with the current SSH/rsync functionality (when disabled, we would fall back to the current SSH/rsync-based functionality). Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: paul-carlton2 Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- 1. Implement the virStorageVolUpload/virStorageVolDownload code in the :code:`migrate_disk_and_power_off` method, as an alternative to the existing calls to :code:`libvirt_utils.copy_image`. 2. Follow Up: remove the instances of SSH that are used to set up and tear down the migration (e.g. for shared storage detection). These could easily be done in a manner similar to how live migration works (having pre_migrate_host and pre_migrate_dest methods, instead of SSHing). Dependencies ============ `Use libvirt storage pools`_ .. _Use libvirt storage pools: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/use-libvirt-storage-pools Testing ======= Since this only changes how migration works under the hood, existing migration tests could simply be run again with the :code:`[libvirt]vol_upload_migration` configuration option enabled on a setup where the libvirt storage pool image backend is also in use. One potential location to enable these code paths is the "bleeding edge" libvirt tests which are being created. Documentation Impact ==================== For the OpenStack Security Guide, we should note that the new functionality can be used as an alternative to deploying SSH access between compute nodes, instead of having to provision SSH keys for the compute nodes, as well as provide instructions for securing remote libvirtd connections. In the Compute Admin Guide, we should provide instructions for how to enable remote libvirtd connections (as required for libvirt live migration), as well as noting that these connections need to be secured, as per the Security Guide. Since much of this documentation also applies to libvirt live migrations, it may be beneficial to place the instructions in a "general" section and link to it from both the libvirt cold migrations and libvirt live migrations documentation. References ========== * http://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt.html#virStorageVolUpload * http://libvirt.org/auth.html) * http://libvirt.org/remote.html#Remote_libvirtd_configuration

commit_message:
Support for Keystone as Service Provider

This patch implements the class to configure Keystone
as a Service Provider. It covers only Keystone as SP
for K2K (Protocol is SAML and module is Shibboleth)

On Debian based systems:
1- Configure keystone.conf
2- Install Shibboleth
3- Reconfigure the selected Keystone VirtualHost on Apache.

On RedHat based systems:
1- Configure keystone.conf
2- Reconfigure the selected Keystone VirtualHost on Apache.
Note: Step 2 will only execute if the user have add the extra repository
or installed shibboleth.
(About the extra repository, see:
https://wiki.shibboleth.net/confluence/display/SHIB2/NativeSPLinuxRPMInstall)

Implements: blueprint enabling-federation
Change-Id: I32a1487c7674605124e6d0b182fe38ea4b58de87
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/21/216821/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'spec_helper' describe 'keystone::federation::service_provider' do describe 'with invalid params' do let :params do { :protocol => 'other'} end it_raises 'a Puppet::Error', /Invalid protocol. Allowed values are: openidc, saml./ before do params.merge!(:protocol => 'saml') end it_raises 'a Puppet::Error', /Invalid module. Allowed values are: shib, mellon./ before do params.merge!(:module => 'shib', :methods => 'external, password, token, oauth1') end it_raises 'a Puppet::Error', /The external method should be dropped to avoid any interference with some Apache + Shibboleth SP setups, where a REMOTE_USER env variable is always set, even as an empty value./ before do params.merge!(:methods => 'password, token, oauth1') end it_raises 'a Puppet::Error', /Methods should contain saml2 as one of the auth methods./ before do params.merge!(:methods => 'password, token, oauth1, saml2', :module_plugin => 'keystone.auth.plugins') end it_raises 'a Puppet:Error', /The plugin for saml and shibboleth should be keystone.auth.plugins.mapped.Mapped/ end describe 'when installing shibboleth with basic params' do let :params do { :protocol => 'saml' :module => 'shib' :methods => 'password, token, saml2' :mapping_plugin => 'keystone.auth.plugins.mapped.Mapped' } end it { is_expected.to contain_package('libapache2-mod-shib2').with( :ensure => 'present', ) } it 'should have basic params for shibboleth' do is_expected.to contain_keystone_config('auth/methods').with_value('password, token, saml2') is_expected.to contain_keystone_config('auth/saml2').with_value('keystone.auth.plugins.mapped.Mapped') end end end

subject: xen: mask passwords in volume connection_data dict
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-19 22:51:38.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/xenapi/volumeops.py', 'nova/tests/unit/virt/xenapi/test_volume_utils.py', 'nova/virt/xenapi/volume_utils.py', 'nova/tests/unit/virt/xenapi/test_volumeops.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/cf197ec2d682fb4da777df2291ca7ef101f73b77', 'message': "xen: mask passwords in volume connection_data dict

The connection_data dict can have credentials in it, so we need to scrub
those before putting the stringified dict into the StorageError message
and raising that up and when logging the dict.

Note that strutils.mask_password converts the dict to a string using
six.text_type so we don't have to do that conversion first.

SecurityImpact

commit_message:
xen: mask passwords in volume connection_data dict

The connection_data dict can have credentials in it, so we need to scrub
those before putting the stringified dict into the StorageError message
and raising that up and when logging the dict.

Note that strutils.mask_password converts the dict to a string using
six.text_type so we don't have to do that conversion first.

SecurityImpact

Change-Id: Ic5f4d4c26794550a92481bf2b725ef5eafa581b2
Closes-Bug: #1516765
(cherry picked from commit 8b289237ed6d53738c22878decf0c429301cf3d0)

commit_message:
Enable update of network properties for nova server profile

This patch adds support for network properties update for
os.nova.server profile type. To update the network definition
of a nova server cluster/node, user can create a new profile instance
with 'networks' spec property changed and then use this new profile
to update cluster/node.

Change-Id: I9f4c8143b543fd689e4c095175753ed353aaa494
Implements: blueprint support-nova-server-update

commit_message:
Drop some outdated information from our quick start guide

* Only tox has to be installed via pip, everything else is in virtual
  environment. Nose is no longer used.
* One should NOT run other tox commands in an existing tox environment.
  This is not how tox is intended to be used, and it cause weird failures
  or seemingly random virtual environment rebuilds.
* Drop statement about running unit tests on a clear VM. Not sure where it
  comes from, only tox and setuptools are required to run unit tests,
  and they don't mess with system packages. Only leave note about devstack,
  as people seem to have problems with it.

Change-Id: Ie7d0172b66231cfd8f9c4f8f2d76604a187443b0

All further commands in this section should be run with the venv active:: source .tox/venv/bin/activate When you're done, deactivate the virtualenv:: deactivate

[image-guide] Fix Debian image download text

The text was one year old, before the release of Jessie.
This patch gives a bit of refresh.

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================================= Server List filter with tenant-id should implies all-tenants flag ================================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/list-filter-with-tenant-id-should-implies-all-tenants Admin request to server list filter with "tenant_id" should implies "all_tenants" flag to get correct list of servers for requested tenant. Problem description =================== When admin tries to list all servers that belong to a given tenant, it works only when the "all_tenant" flag is passed. For example, nova list --tenant xyz --all-tenants 1 If "all_tenants" flag is not mentioned, then it returns empty list with 200 response code. Use Cases --------- Admin want to list all servers belongs to given tenants same way as other list filter works. Project Priority ---------------- None Proposed change =============== Flag "all_tenants" should not be required for "tenant_id" filter to function properly. If admin is searching servers with filter "tenant_id" then, this should imply that all_tenants is also enabled unless that is explicitly disabled. Alternatives ------------ It can be fixed as bug fix without requiring a new API microversion. But to advertise that it is working fine now, microversion.. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Request:: GET /servers?tenant_id=<id> The request and response headers, body and possible codes are unchanged from current behavior. The "tenant_id" filter will work properly. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- python-novaclient will have to be updated so that it can request the new microversion when the "tenant_id" option is used in server list API. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: gmann Work Items ---------- * Add a new microversion and change v3/server.py to make "tenant_id" filter work properly. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Unit tests and API samples functional tests in the nova tree will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== The nova/api/openstack/rest_api_version_history.rst document will be updated. References ========== [1] Originally reported as a bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1185290 [2] Reopened bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1468992 [3] Proof of concept code change: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/195412/3 (Need to undo for v2)

commit_message:
Proposed the fix-resize-migration-for-pci-devices for Mitaka

Change-Id: Id79f585b12ee4ab7fce115f312b3868f9637d350
Implements: blueprint fix-resize-migration-for-pci-devices
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/23/239123/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ﻿.. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================================== Support for resize/migration for instances with PCI devices =========================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/fix-resize-migration-for-pci-devices Since Icehouse, an instance with PCI devices can't get resized or migrated successfully. The PCI devices are not being claimed/allocated based on the new PCI request or based on PCI devices that are available on the migrated server. This blueprint addresses this issue. Problem description =================== The issue with resizing and migrating an instance with PCI devices has been documented and raised in launchpad, see references. The bugs are marked low and medium priority respectively. Priority should be revised, we believe that this is quite important for applications that are deployed in the cloud that necessitate high availability and do require accelerated hardware functions. Some attempts have been made to fix those issues, but unfortunately no fix is available at the moment (first issue was reported in September 2014). These issues are being addressed in a blueprint because they are not a simple fix and it requires a big effort in order to deliver a solution. The solution will be delivered in multiple commits. Depending on the action (resize, or migrate) that is being requested by a user for a given instance, a new set of PCI devices has to be claimed and allocated to the instance. The user specifies the type and the number of PCI devices it requires in the flavor (using the key :code:`pci_passthrough:alias` ). During a resize, it's possible to add more PCI devices to an instance as well as remove some of them. Therefore, PCI devices might need to get allocated from the pool of PCI devices for a given compute, or they might be put back in the pool when the user needs fewer devices than previously specified. Another consideration to deal with is that a resize can actually spawn an instance on a different compute. When an instance needs to be migrated to another server (because of a planned migration or for a forced evacuation after a fault has been detected on a server), new PCI devices need to be allocated to the instance. Currently, nova tries to use the same set of PCI devices that were allocated on the incoming server and use them on the migrated server. Servers are rarely using the same configuration of PCI devices and are most likely have different PCI addresses. Trying to re-use the same PCI devices/addresses on the migrated server results in a qemu/kvm error when spawning the instance because it tries to use a non-existent PCI device or it tries to use a device than is already used/allocated by another guest. Extra work is needed in the case where an instance need access to an SR-IOV PCI devices for accelerated virtual NIC support. These devices require the user to create a Neutron port of type direct beforehand (for e.g., :code:`neutron port-create <net-id> --binding:vnic-type direct`). Therefore, each PCI devices for those virtual functions (VFs) have a corresponding Neutron port associated with them. These Neutron ports contain information about the PCI device that is being used (PCI address, vendor and product, etc.). The Nova libvirt driver uses this information for generating a corresponding interface in the instance XML file. Therefore, when new PCI devices are allocated to an instance we also need to update their corresponding Neutron ports with the correct PCI device information. Use Cases ---------- An end-user may currently decide to use PCI-passthrough or SRIOV for performance reasons. The operator should be able to migrate these instances to other nodes for maintenance purposes, and the end-user should be able to resize the instance as needed. As presented earlier, there are two major use cases to consider: 1. Resize of an instance with more or less PCI devices than previously specified, a resize is issued by an end user. Adding or removing on interfaces is required post deployment to handle more or less traffic or computation power depending on user requirements. 2. Migration or evacuation of an instance to a different compute. Migration to a different compute could be required for maintenance actions. In this case it is either triggered by a fault detection which will automate the evacuation or by the administrator if it's a planned migration. Proposed change =============== This solution involve changing multiple components in Nova. The PciDevTracker class which is responsible for allocating the PCI devices based on the flavor or the PCI request, need to be modified so that it can detect and do the proper actions if PCI devices need to be allocated or de-allocated. In the PciDevTracker class, most of the changes required are located in the following method: .. code:: python def update_pci_for_migration(self, context, instance, sign=1): This method needs to be slightly modified to make sure new PCI devices are getting claimed and allocated based on the PCI request or the new Flavor. If an instance is getting resized on the same node, some of the PCI devices don't need to be re-allocated, allocation of new PCI devices if only needed to be done if the new flavors is requiring more devices than anticipated. There are a few fixes required in the ComputeManager class. For some of the instance actions (for e.g., rebuild_instance), the network_info is taken from the info_cache in the instance metadata (see calls to :code:`compute_utils.get_nw_info_for_instance()`). This data contains stale information about the PCI devices that were previously assigned. Here we need to make sure that the cache information is rebuilt by calling self._get_instance_nw_info(). Another code change that is needed is the support for updating the Neutron port on assignment of new PCI devices to an instance. Changes will mostly be isolated in the Neutronv2 API class. The API will be responsible to update the Neutron port information and send the update to Neutron. The networking info cache also need to be updated accordingly since the libvirt driver is using this information to output the interfaces in the instance XML. The PCI information for a given PCI device is defined as follow in the port structure: :code:`'binding:profile': {u'pci_slot': u'0000:87:13.3', u'physical_network': u'physnet2', u'pci_vendor_info': u'8086:10ed'}` The changes require are limited to the implementation of the following method in the Neutronv2 API class: .. code:: python def _update_port_binding_for_instance(self, context, instance, host): This method will be modified to modify the PCI information for every ports that has a binding:vnic_type of type direct. For each of those port we need to correlate which Neutron ports correspond to which PCI devices allocated to the instance. For this purpose we propose to also include the pci_request_id in the binding:profile (note that the pci_request_id will also need to be populated when the instance is spawn for the first time, see method allocate_for_instance). Once a port has been corroletad to it's new PCI device, the port is updated with the correct information. Lastly, a call to the Neutron server is executed for updating the ports. This information is needed by the Libvirt driver for constructed the interfaces for the modified PCI devices (see method _get_guest_config() in the LibvirtDriver driver, which iterate through all the vif contained in the network_info). Other type of PCI devices are processed elsewhere in the same method, they are not binded to any networks therefore they are not present in the network_info. Note that SR-IOV PCI devices for virtual NIC are outputted as an interface (for e.g., :code:`<interface type='hostdev' managed='yes'>`) in the XML instance file. Other PCI devices are simply exported as normal PCI devices to the guest (for e.g. :code:`<hostdev mode='subsystem' type='pci' managed='yes'>`) Alternatives ------------ None. We are proposing to re-use the same mechanisms and framework already in place. The changes are for bug fixing not a re-write or refactoring of the resize/migration feature. Therefore the solution is fairly straight forward. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. The code impacted is only triggered during a resize or a migration. Other deployer impact --------------------- The fix will need to be deployed on all computes. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ludovic.beliveau (ludovic.beliveau@windriver.com) WindRiver is committed to provide the effort for implementing this feature. Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. * Fix the PciDevTracker class to claim/allocate PCI devices according to the new requirements for an instance. * Fix the ComputeManager class to update the network_info data with the new PCI devices. * Modify the pci framework to allocate/deallocate the PCI devices based on the new flavor or based on the hardware found on the migrated server. * Modify the Neutronv2 API to update the ports based on the PCI devices that have been updated. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= We suggest that one or more tempest test to be added to validate the correct functionality of the patch. Existence of PCI devices is dependent on hardware and it is hard to validate in a virtual environment. Using unit tests to validate that PCI devices have been correctly assigned (or un-assigned) to an instance is relatively easy, but we suggest that complete system test is executed, especially validation of PCI device functionality (for e.g., for a NIC device validate that network connectivity is working, for a cryptographic device validate that the guest can encrypt/decrypt correctly, etc.). For this reason, we are proposing that a tempest test be added to the Intel PCI CI Jenkins check. The following unit tests should be implemented: * Resize of an instance with a new flavor that has less PCI devices that the original flavor on the same compute and on a different compute (validation needs to be done on a flavor that is asking for more than one PCI device of a given type). * Resize of an instance with a new flavor that has more PCI devices that the original flavor on the same compute and on a different compute . * Migration of an instance on a compute that has a different set of PCI devices with different PCI addresses. * Validate PCI passthrough devices (PF) and SR-IOV PCI devices (VF). * Validate with other type of devices (for e.g., cryptographic hardware acceleration). * Validate that PCI stats are valid after a resize or a migration. Negative testing has to be validated as well (expected failure). Documentation Impact ==================== None. References ========== * https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1368201 * https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1400784

commit_message:
sql sharding support

Change-Id: Ib2d24275242bec68a358382387fef09b86deb211
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/56/197356/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================== SQL Sharding Support ==================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/sharding-sql Ceilometer offers different backend options to store meter data: sql, mongodb, and hbase. While mongodb is often mentioned as the recommended metering backend, SQL may be a more viable option. Problem description =================== In large scale deployments, a single instance of a db, whether it be mongodb, mysql, or postgres, will not scale to accommodate the data load. In many enviroments, the amount of data received can be in the order of gigabytes per minute. To manage this scale, the ability to easily write and read from multiple databsae instances is required. Proposed change =============== SQLAlchemy provides the ability to have sharded session to enable spreading the data across multiple database targets. This will minimise the size of the db instance, localise queries, and distribute load. Doing so will enable better write and read response. The shard key will be configured by project_id and resource_id. This seems to be the main use case for those needing telemetry in production. Using the hash of those ids, we can bucketise the datapoints into a defined number of shards. This ability will allow for greater storage capabilities but will also include some complexities. For one, we do not support adding/dropping shards as the data is sharded out to specific database instance. Also, the management of multiple databases will require more management requirements. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None, based on internal testing, the SQL model seems to be much more efficient compared to mongodb. REST API impact --------------- None, SQLAlchemy sharded sessions will handle interface. Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None, this is unrelated to the feature request for more granular control in pipeline. Other end user impact --------------------- Adding an option to enable sharding in sql as well as the number of db. Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- This is a requirement for running SQL backend at scale. Other deployer impact --------------------- If enabled, deployers must manage multiple instances of database Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Ongoing maintainer: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- - add shardsession support to metering driver Future lifecycle ================ add same support to gnocchi indexer Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== document new options References ========== - http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/_modules/examples/sharding/attribute_shard.html

commit_message:
Wrong entity name for Host Aggregate resource

The entity name is used by resource.
This cause unable to show or delete the aggregate.

commit_message:
Implement OpenStack client clouds.yml configuration file

OpenStack client supports defining one or more sets of credentials
inside a clouds.yml configuration file. A default configuration has
been created named `default` that contains the same admin credentials
from the `openrc` file currently being templated.

The default configuration can be specified using the following:

openstack --os-cloud default <command>

Change-Id: I62ac6fad7165cb07c551cdcf503e50ccd3cd3a56

commit_message:
Fix HTTP error codes due to invalid templates

This reverts commit 9a4d719ea1a6ca63f527b5c78308fd288058d42b and creates a
new exception type, InvalidGlobalResource, that is raised when a
non-existent template is referenced in the global environment and which
results in an HTTP 500 error.

This fixes the cases where we could return 404 or 500 errors as a result of
template validation failures, when we should return a 400 error.

Change-Id: I3c7b3182957448bb13514696cc2e12f5aaddd253
Closes-Bug: #1518458
Related-Bug: #1447194

commit_message:
Refactor the test for Fuel Master migration

Refactor the test to use template based approach:
- refactor the test to use template driven engine;
- add a new nodes config - 1 controller + 1 compute;
- add 2 new test configs - for VLAN and VXLAN net. providers
that use the new '1 controller + 1 compute' nodes config.

Change-Id: I586103f144bab73aa69b4239944ddf128919202b
Closes-bug: #1512677

commit_message:
remove unnecessary mock for rpc server start

latest oslo.messaging 3.0.0 requires invoking start() first then stop()
can be called, but we've mocked the start() which will hang the process
then finally raise TimeoutException.

This patch removes unnecessary mock for rpc server start(), and bumps
oslo.messaging to align with global requirements.

Change-Id: If22df56a3b3af1e62b9f29fa1be1276d7cf7776d
Closes-Bug: #1519182
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/aodh refs/changes/91/248991/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.service.start() self.service.stop()
deleted_lines: # If we try to create a real RPC connection, init_host() never # returns. Mock it out so we can establish the service # configuration. with mock.patch.object(self.service.rpc_server, 'start'): self.service.start() self.service.stop()

commit_message:
As discussed with Shuquan, I applied some changes:

* Retrieved subnet & mask bits (IPv4 & IPv6) from a new value in tempest conf file
* Check if the mask bits is not too small

Change-Id: I60e29f307c7932c4b5b3f121a166521e21d2a737
Closes-Bug: #1514457
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/82/249182/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.IntOpt('test_port_network_v4_cidr', default="192.168.0.0/24", help="The cidr block to allocate ipv4 subnets for" " create_ports test"), cfg.IntOpt('test_port_network_v6_cidr', default="2003::/64", help="The cidr block to allocate ipv6 subnets for" " create_ports test"),

commit_message:
Remove _keystone_identity method

_keystone_identity method has been maintained for backward
compatibility. But there is no place to use it now so this patch
replace _keystone_identity method to _integrated_keystone_identity
method as _keystone_identity.

Change-Id: I9464c047401f92ae31a5d3bb7aacaeb0624150e0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/50/204050/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: env_identity = self._keystone_identity(environ) if env_identity: self.logger.debug('Using identity: %r', env_identity) environ['REMOTE_USER'] = env_identity.get('tenant') user_roles = (r.lower() for r in env_identity.get('roles', []))
deleted_lines: identity = self._keystone_identity(environ) if identity: self.logger.debug('Using identity: %r', identity) environ['keystone.identity'] = identity environ['REMOTE_USER'] = identity.get('tenant') env_identity = self._integral_keystone_identity(environ) user_roles = (r.lower() for r in identity.get('roles', [])) # In next release, we would add user id in env['keystone.identity'] by # using _integral_keystone_identity to replace current # _keystone_identity. The purpose of keeping it in this release it for # back compatibility. identity = {'user': environ.get('HTTP_X_USER_NAME'), 'tenant': (environ.get('HTTP_X_TENANT_ID'), environ.get('HTTP_X_TENANT_NAME')), 'roles': roles} return identity def _integral_keystone_identity(self, environ): """Extract the identity from the Keystone auth component.""" if environ.get('HTTP_X_IDENTITY_STATUS') != 'Confirmed': return roles = list_from_csv(environ.get('HTTP_X_ROLES', ''))

subject: Public environment template
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-21 09:24:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano/commit/39bb1d2ddea2ca0e1c722a37ada997ddfa1eff93', 'message': 'Abstract environment template catalogue.

Continuing with the environment template catalog blueprint,
which allowed to define complex architecture for applications,
 an abstract environment template catalog can be included.
It involves the existence of an environment template catalogue independent on any user, which can be customized by anyone to include their concrete information (e.g. keypair). Concretely, it involves all the operations to manage environment templates (creation, deletion, updating), plus the customization done by the user. At the end, the customized environment template can be lanched and converted into an enviornment

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/murano/+spec/abstract-env-template

Change-Id: I702d9d707cb14195278b1cc2084fe9609660a3fe

commit_message:
Public environment template

This feature will allow having private and public environment templates, as well as,
to obtain all public templates from all tenants. In addition, a clone functionality
is added to copy a template from a tenant to another.

Change-Id: I702d9d707cb14195278b1cc2084fe9609660a3fe
Targets-blueprint: abstract-env-template

commit_message:
Let cluster-update return 400 if profile not found

This is part of a series of patches that correct the returned status
code when some referenced object cannot be found when performing
operations on some entities.

Change-Id: I74c595deff1784f24f27d1c810df08faf10bebc5
Partial-Bug: #1518209
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/82/247982/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: mock_find = self.patchobject(self.eng, 'profile_find') mock_find.side_effect = [ self.profile, exception.ProfileNotFound(profile='Bogus') ] self.assertEqual(exception.SenlinBadRequest, ex.exc_info[0]) self.assertEqual("The request is malformed: " "The specified profile 'Bogus' is not found.", six.text_type(ex.exc_info[1]))

commit_message:
Change admin IP ranges in tests for node groups

Change default IP addresses range for admin/pxe network
in system test for multiple cluster networks feature.
Check that DHCP range is configured properly and Nailgun
doesn't allocate excluded from range IPs to nodes.

Change-Id: I64069e287a6970b93931d93212efb0c1712af40a
Closes-bug: #1513154
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/77/248477/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ipaddr import summarize_address_range from devops.helpers.helpers import wait @staticmethod def change_default_admin_range(networks, exclude_first_ips): default_admin_network = [n for n in networks if (n['name'] == "fuelweb_admin" and n['group_id'] is None)] assert_true(len(default_admin_network) == 1, "Default 'admin/pxe' network not found " "in cluster network configuration!") default_admin_range = [IPAddress(ip) for ip in default_admin_network[0]["ip_ranges"][0]] new_admin_range = [default_admin_range[0] + exclude_first_ips, default_admin_range[1]] default_admin_network[0]["ip_ranges"][0] = [str(ip) for ip in new_admin_range] return default_admin_network[0]["ip_ranges"][0] @staticmethod def is_ip_in_range(ip_addr, ip_range_start, ip_range_end): ip_addr_ranges = summarize_address_range(IPAddress(ip_range_start), IPAddress(ip_range_end)) return any(IPAddress(ip_addr) in iprange for iprange in ip_addr_ranges) @staticmethod def is_update_dnsmasq_running(tasks): for task in tasks: if task['name'] == "update_dnsmasq" and \ task["status"] == "running": return True return False 2. Create cluster with Neutron VXLAN, Ceph and custom nodegroup 3. Exclude 10 first IPs from range for default admin/pxe network 4. Bootstrap slave nodes from both default and custom nodegroups 5. Check that excluded IPs aren't allocated to discovered nodes 6. Add 3 controller + ceph nodes from default nodegroup 7. Add 2 compute + ceph nodes from custom nodegroup 8. Deploy cluster 9. Run network verification 10. Run health checks (OSTF) 11. Check that excluded IPs aren't allocated to deployed nodes self.show_step(3) networks = self.fuel_web.client.get_networks(cluster_id)["networks"] new_admin_range = self.change_default_admin_range(networks, exclude_first_ips=10) wait(lambda: not self.is_update_dnsmasq_running( self.fuel_web.client.get_tasks()), timeout=60, timeout_msg="Timeout exceeded while waiting for task " "'update_dnsmasq' is finished!") self.fuel_web.client.update_network(cluster_id, networks=networks) logger.info("New addresses range for default admin network:" " {0}".format(new_admin_range)) self.env.bootstrap_nodes(self.env.d_env.nodes().slaves[0:5]) default_ng_nodes = [self.fuel_web.get_nailgun_node_by_devops_node(node) for node in self.env.d_env.nodes().slaves[0:5:2]] for node in default_ng_nodes: assert_true(self.is_ip_in_range(node['ip'], *new_admin_range), "Node '{0}' has IP address '{1}' which " "is not from defined IP addresses range:" " {2}!".format(node['fqdn'], node['ip'], new_admin_range)) self.show_step(7) self.fuel_web.deploy_cluster_wait(cluster_id, timeout=150 * 60) self.fuel_web.verify_network(cluster_id) self.show_step(10) self.show_step(11) group_id = self.fuel_web.get_nodegroup(cluster_id, name=nodegroup_default)['id'] default_ng_nodes = [node for node in self.fuel_web.client.list_cluster_nodes(cluster_id) if node['group_id'] == group_id] for node in default_ng_nodes: assert_true(self.is_ip_in_range(node['ip'], *new_admin_range), "Node '{0}' has IP address '{1}' which " "is not from defined IP addresses range:" " {2}!".format(node['fqdn'], node['ip'], new_admin_range))

commit_message:
Add 'mutable' param to Opt

re: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/mitaka-cross-project-dynamic-config-services

oslo.config already offers a reload_config_files method. This patch adds
a 'mutable' flag to Opt, allowing services to mark which opts may be
reloaded. It also adds a flag to ConfigOpts, 'limit_mutation', to say
that when reload_config_files is called, only mutable opts should be
changed. If a new value for an immutable opt is detected, a warning is
issued.

Change-Id: I719874b58e64bc4f8535c85da43670779fbfd380
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config refs/changes/04/246404/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :param mutable: True if this option should be reloaded in response to SIGHUP deprecated_for_removal=False, mutable=False): self.mutable = mutable def set(self, section, name, value): for sections in self.parsed: if name in sections[section]: sections[section][name] = value break else: sections = {section: {name: value}} normalized = {_normalize_group_name(section): {name: value}} self._add_parsed_config_file(sections, normalized) def _set_value(self, section, name, value, cli=False): if cli: name = name if section is None else section + '_' + name setattr(self, name, value) else: self._parser.set(section, name, value) self.allow_mutate = False self.mutation_hook = None if self.allow_mutate: self._mutate(namespace) return True def _mutate(self, namespace): fresh = {} for info, group in self._all_opt_infos(): opt = info['opt'] groupname = group.name if group else None if opt.name in ['config-dir', 'config-file']: continue old = opt._get_from_namespace(self._namespace, groupname) new = opt._get_from_namespace(namespace, groupname) if old == new: continue if opt.mutable: fresh[(groupname, opt.name)] = ( {'value': new, 'cli': info['cli']}) else: LOG.warn("Ignoring change to immutable option: %s" % opt.name) if fresh and self.mutation_hook: # Old options are still available from CONF during this call. self.mutation_hook(fresh) for key, item in fresh.items(): self._namespace._set_value( key[0], key[1], item['value'], item['cli'])

commit_message:
Make snapshot-name argument positional

Make "snapshot-name" argument mandatory
to avoid misunderstandings

Change-Id: I59a5723b8630068af8d947ea8903b007f98071c0
Closes-Bug: #1461079

commit_message:
Let cluster-create return 400 if profile not found

This is part of a series of patches to come that fix the return status
code of the HTTP API request. When referenced objects (not the entity
itself) is not found, we should return 400 (bad request) instead of 404
(not found).

Change-Id: I14a2dfed744ca41a1f288d14fe052c698f223827
Partial-Bug: #1518209
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/66/247966/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-20 01:57:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/commit/b78374a998d2fb7f352f2d4cfd7748ad369b9cbe', 'message': 'Fix with-items concurrency greater than the number of items

Change-Id: Ib9425f00a735c2fa09b685486aff02511094d991
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-11-20 18:01:17.000000000', 'files': ['mistral/workflow/with_items.py', 'mistral/tests/unit/engine/test_with_items.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/commit/e858a26f50222cef688c48d3fc0129a0d9b2995b', 'message': 'Fix with-items concurrency greater than the number of items

commit_message:
Fix with-items concurrency greater than the number of items

If the list provided to with-items has length less than the value provided
in concurrency, the engine throws an exception index out of range.

Change-Id: Ib9425f00a735c2fa09b685486aff02511094d991
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/77/247877/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_with_items_concurrency_gt_list_length(self): workflow_definition = """--- version: "2.0" concurrency_test: type: direct input: - names: ["John", "Ivan"] tasks: task1: with-items: name in <% $.names %> action: std.echo output=<% $.name %> concurrency: 3 """ wf_service.create_workflows(workflow_definition) # Start workflow. wf_ex = self.engine.start_workflow('concurrency_test', {}) self._await( lambda: self.is_execution_success(wf_ex.id), ) wf_ex = db_api.get_execution(wf_ex.id) task_ex = self._assert_single_item(wf_ex.task_executions, name='task1') result = data_flow.get_task_execution_result(task_ex) self.assertEqual(states.SUCCESS, task_ex.state) self.assertTrue(isinstance(result, list)) self.assertIn('John', result) self.assertIn('Ivan', result)

commit_message:
Remove preprov provider dependencies from CONF

This commit removes the last dependencie of the preprov
provider from CONF. The required configuration is passed
now as parameters at init time.

As the number of parameter grows, and many of them are taken from
configuration, adding dicts with parameters that can be used
when instantiating the credentials providers.

Depends-on: I0ca0b96fc618ffe60851984a9c6d46b0507878d4
Partially-implements: bp tempest-library
Change-Id: I945994580ce9a29f6fbf67183e5da4b100542386

subject: Refactor firewall to listen on only on internal networks
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-13 14:48:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/8941dff9ec4fc3510df5e641b72c10eeb3ba40d0', 'message': '(WIP) Block services on public network

Refactors firewall rules to create source
based rules that only permit connections
from the management network for most services.

The only services that should have public access
are Horizon and OpenStack APIs. And from those,
nova metadata and nova VNC should only be
accessible internally. All other services should
accept connections from private or storage
networks.

New defined type openstack::firewall::multi_net
accepts firewall definitions with an array of
source networks.

Removed unneeded openstack::firewall::allow class.
Obsoleted openstack::firewall:vnc defined type.

Change-Id: Ie63c01dcbd0bbd9adf17363b0db0b0a99b837b4e
Closes-Bug: #1514014

commit_message:
Refactor firewall to listen on only on internal networks

Refactors firewall rules to create source
based rules that only permit connections
from the management network for most services.

The only services that should have public access
are Horizon and OpenStack APIs. And from those,
nova metadata and nova VNC should only be
accessible internally. All other services should
accept connections from private or storage
networks.

New defined type openstack::firewall::multi_net
accepts firewall definitions with an array of
source networks.

New function prepare_firewall_rules creates a hash
of firewall rules coming from an array of source
networks.

Removed unneeded openstack::firewall::allow class.
Obsoleted openstack::firewall:vnc defined type.

Sorted parameters on openstack::firewall and added
docstrings

DocImpact: TBD

Change-Id: Ie63c01dcbd0bbd9adf17363b0db0b0a99b837b4e
Closes-Bug: #1514014

commit_message:
Networks tab does not show external configuration

When you create a network you can specify it as
external network. When the network is listed
in Horizon 'Networks' tab we do not see any
column indicating if network is 'external' .
It is nice to enhance the network tab to add a
new column showing 'external' indicating whether
network is 'external'.

Change-Id: I5cbd612b47f842fcb669b72ee4bf076ccd554356
Close-Bug:#1350237

commit_message:
msgpackutils: drop Python 2.6 support

We doesn't support python 2.6 now, this commit
removes Python 2.6 related code in module msgpackutls.

Change-Id: Id148239ee6c1ad461188fa38b06ca0d7913d7454

deleted_lines: is_simplejson = False if sys.version_info < (2, 7): # On Python <= 2.6, json module is not C boosted, so try to use # simplejson module if available try: import simplejson as json # NOTE(mriedem): Make sure we have a new enough version of simplejson # to support the namedobject_as_tuple argument. This can be removed # in the Kilo release when python 2.6 support is dropped. if 'namedtuple_as_object' in inspect.getargspec(json.dumps).args: is_simplejson = True else: import json except ImportError: import json else: import json if is_simplejson: kwargs['namedtuple_as_object'] = False if is_simplejson: kwargs['namedtuple_as_object'] = False

commit_message:
Align requirements to liberty global-requirements

Now requirements.txt and test-requirements.txt are
aligned to global-requirements.txt of stable/Liberty.

Testing requirements are now move to test-requirements.txt
from tox.ini

Also the author, author-email and home-page are now update to
reflect Freezer Team and openstack-dev ml.

Change-Id: I27f2ea875778f19d2ffb542b9b8fbf29d1a740fe

'}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2015-11-11 08:39:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-devops/commit/08dcb8d47a0f3d31e2e5894933f542d4ca20410c', 'message': "Move to template-based configuration of devops environments

To create a devops virtual environment (networks, volumes, nodes),
now can be used YAML template desctibed in [1].

How it can be used:

* New approach, environment will be created using the data from
  full_config object:

  environment.create_environment(full_config)

* Old-style approach (deprecated), in this case at first will be
  created a 'full_config' object using shell environment variables,
  and then called environment.create_environment(full_config):

  environment.describe_environment(boot_from='cdrom'):

* Override old-style approach, in this case the YAML config will
  be taken from the file located in DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE shell
  environment variable instead of variables from settings.py:

  export DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE=/tmp/some_template_file.yaml

- add create_envoronment() method that creates environment from
  provided config
- add template generator for keep legacy behaviour of the
  method describe_environment()
- Environment.define() is deprecated and left for back compatibility
  with older fuel-qa branches
- Some objects in template require the extended database schema,
  so in this patch there are some workarounds to use templates with
  original schema (particular data from address_pools and
  l2_network_devices are stored in the Network model)

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240170/

Change-Id: Iad081bee94c4d3b404eda57b7c1c31011b837ba7
Implements: blueprint template-based-testcases
"}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2015-11-11 08:48:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-devops/commit/cf7054822520a0d509341931912babb2f2b1cf25', 'message': "Move to template-based configuration of devops environments

To create a devops virtual environment (networks, volumes, nodes),
now can be used YAML template desctibed in [1].

How it can be used:

* New approach, environment will be created using the data from
  full_config object:

  environment.create_environment(full_config)

* Old-style approach (deprecated), in this case at first will be
  created a 'full_config' object using shell environment variables,
  and then called environment.create_environment(full_config):

  environment.describe_environment(boot_from='cdrom'):

* Override old-style approach, in this case the YAML config will
  be read from the file located in DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE shell
  environment variable to the 'full_config' object and passed to
  create_environment(full_config); creating config in old-style
  will be skipped:

  export DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE=/tmp/some_template_file.yaml

- add create_envoronment() method that creates environment from
  provided config
- add template generator for keep legacy behaviour of the
  method describe_environment()
- Environment.define() is deprecated and left for back compatibility
  with older fuel-qa branches
- Some objects in template require the extended database schema,
  so in this patch there are some workarounds to use templates with
  original schema (particular data from address_pools and
  l2_network_devices are stored in the Network model)

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240170/

Change-Id: Iad081bee94c4d3b404eda57b7c1c31011b837ba7
Implements: blueprint template-based-testcases
"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2015-11-11 14:35:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-devops/commit/6dbfa0e5851a2292cc5a435e88425174bf228b76', 'message': "Move to template-based configuration of devops environments

To create a devops virtual environment (networks, volumes, nodes),
now can be used YAML template desctibed in [1].

How it can be used:

* New approach, environment will be created using the data from
  full_config object:

  environment.create_environment(full_config)

* Old-style approach (deprecated), in this case at first will be
  created a 'full_config' object using shell environment variables,
  and then called environment.create_environment(full_config):

  environment.describe_environment(boot_from='cdrom'):

* Override old-style approach, in this case the YAML config will
  be read from the file located in DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE shell
  environment variable to the 'full_config' object and passed to
  create_environment(full_config); creating config in old-style
  will be skipped:

  export DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE=/tmp/some_template_file.yaml

- add create_envoronment() method that creates environment from
  provided config. There is performed define() and describe()
  actions for each object, so calling environment.describe() is not
  required later.
- add template generator for keep legacy behaviour of the
  method describe_environment()
- Environment.define() is deprecated and left for back compatibility
  with older fuel-qa branches
- Some objects in template require the extended database schema,
  so in this patch there are some workarounds to use templates with
  original schema (particular data from address_pools and
  l2_network_devices are stored in the Network model)

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240170/

Change-Id: Iad081bee94c4d3b404eda57b7c1c31011b837ba7
Implements: blueprint template-based-testcases

To create a devops virtual environment (networks, volumes, nodes),
now can be used YAML template desctibed in [1].

How it can be used:

* New approach, environment will be created using the data from
  full_config object:

  environment.create_environment(full_config)

* Old-style approach (deprecated), in this case at first will be
  created a 'full_config' object using shell environment variables,
  and then called environment.create_environment(full_config):

  environment.describe_environment(boot_from='cdrom'):

* Override old-style approach, in this case the YAML config will
  be read from the file located in DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE shell
  environment variable to the 'full_config' object and passed to
  create_environment(full_config); creating config in old-style
  will be skipped:

  export DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE=/tmp/some_template_file.yaml

- add create_envoronment() method that creates environment from
  provided config.

  database schema be implemented, where all necessary details could
  be passed from define() to desctibe() via database objects.

  method describe_environment()

  with older fuel-qa branches
- Some objects in template require the extended database schema,
  so in this patch there are some workarounds to use templates with
  original schema (particular data from address_pools and
  l2_network_devices are stored in the Network model)

commit_message:
Move to template-based configuration of devops environments

To create a devops virtual environment (networks, volumes, nodes),
now can be used YAML template desctibed in [1].

How it can be used:

* New approach, environment will be created using the data from
  full_config object:

  environment.create_environment(full_config)

* Old-style approach (deprecated), in this case at first will be
  created a 'full_config' object using shell environment variables,
  and then called environment.create_environment(full_config):

  environment.describe_environment(boot_from='cdrom'):

* Override old-style approach, in this case the YAML config will
  be read from the file located in DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE shell
  environment variable to the 'full_config' object and passed to
  create_environment(full_config); creating config in old-style
  will be skipped:

  export DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE=/tmp/some_template_file.yaml

- add create_envoronment() method that creates environment from
  provided config.
- environment.describe() method is temporary disabled until new
  database schema be implemented, where all necessary details could
  be passed from define() to desctibe() via database objects.
- add template generator for keep legacy behaviour of the
  method describe_environment()
- Environment.define() is deprecated and left for back compatibility
  with older fuel-qa branches
- Some objects in template require the extended database schema,
  so in this patch there are some workarounds to use templates with
  original schema (particular data from address_pools and
  l2_network_devices are stored in the Network model)

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240170/

Change-Id: Iad081bee94c4d3b404eda57b7c1c31011b837ba7
Implements: blueprint template-based-virtual-devops-environments
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-devops refs/changes/05/238105/25 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from devops.helpers.templates import get_devops_config from devops.helpers.templates import create_devops_config def add_empty_volume(self, node, name, capacity, def define(self, skip=True): """Define resources Method deprecated, it should be used only with describe_environment() Left here for back compatibility with fuel-qa. """ if not skip: for network in self.get_networks(): network.define() for volume in self.get_volumes(): volume.define() for node in self.get_nodes(): node.define() ################## # import ipdb # ipdb.set_trace() """This method is DEPRECATED. Reserved for backward compatibility only. Please use self.create_environment() instead. """ if settings.DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE: config = get_devops_config(settings.DEVOPS_SETTINGS_TEMPLATE)['template'] else: config = create_devops_config( boot_from=boot_from, env_name=settings.ENV_NAME, admin_vcpu=settings.HARDWARE["admin_node_cpu"], admin_memory=settings.HARDWARE["admin_node_memory"], admin_sysvolume_capacity=settings.ADMIN_NODE_VOLUME_SIZE, admin_iso_path=settings.ISO_PATH, nodes_count=settings.NODES_COUNT, slave_vcpu=settings.HARDWARE["slave_node_cpu"], slave_memory=settings.HARDWARE["slave_node_memory"], slave_volume_capacity=settings.NODE_VOLUME_SIZE, use_all_disks=settings.USE_ALL_DISKS, ironic_nodes_count=settings.IRONIC_NODES_COUNT, ) environment = cls.create_environment(config) return environment @classmethod def create_environment(cls, full_config): config = full_config['devops_settings'] environment = cls.create(config['env_name']) # Create networks # Workaround: create dicts for different network types # TODO:(ddmitriev): describe networks in config networks_to_describe = networks if settings.MULTIPLE_NETWORKS: # If slave index is even number, then attach to # it virtual networks from the second network group, # if it is odd, then attach from the first network group. nodegroups_idx = 1 - int(name[-2:]) % 2 networks_to_describe = [ net for net in networks if net.name in settings.NODEGROUPS[nodegroups_idx]['pools'] ] ironic_net = [] for net in networks: if net.name == 'ironic': ironic_net.append(net) networks_dict = { 'admin': networks, 'slave': networks_to_describe, 'ironic': ironic_net, } # Create nodes: for config_node in config['nodes']: environment.create_node(config_node, networks_dict) net = Network.network_create( net.define() return net def create_node(self, config_node, networks_dict): name=config_node['name'], memory=config_node.get('memory', 2572), vcpu=config_node.get('vcpu', 1), boot=config_node.get('boot', None), role=config_node.get('role', None)) # Temporary workaround networks = networks_dict[config_node.get('networks', 'slave')] for volume in config_node.get('volumes', None): if 'source_image' in volume: disk = self.add_empty_volume( node, volume['name'], capacity=_get_file_size(volume['source_image']), format=volume.get('format', 'qcow2'), device=volume.get('device', 'disk'), bus=volume.get('bus', 'virtio') ) disk.volume.define() disk.volume.upload(volume['source_image']) else: disk = self.add_empty_volume( node, volume['name'], capacity=int(volume['capacity']) * 1024 ** 3, format=volume.get('format', 'qcow2'), device=volume.get('device', 'disk'), bus=volume.get('bus', 'virtio') ) disk.volume.define() node.define() def nodes(self): # migrated from EnvironmentModel.nodes() #DEPRECATED. Please use environment.get_nodes() instead. return Nodes(self) def __init__(self, environment): list(environment.get_nodes(role='fuel_admin')), list(environment.get_nodes(role='fuel_slave')), list(environment.get_nodes(role='ironic')),
